info.game_comments:
Missing contestant introductions and first 9 clues of the Jeopardy! Round.
The BASEBALL GREATS category may have been in column 5.

(1, 1).clue: Completes JFK's quote, "My fellow Americans: ask not what your country can do for you..."
(1, 1).correct response: "ask what you can do for your country."

(2, 1).clue: From the word "body", it's the fitted part of a dress from the waist to the shoulder

(3, 1).clue: The 2 blue stripes on Guatemala's flag represent these 2 oceans

(6, 1).clue: I'm the architect of rock & roll & the originator--Good golly, Miss Molly!

(1, 2).clue: In 1964 he told the GOP convention that "Extremism in the defense of liberty is no vice"

(2, 2).clue: French cuffs are folded back on themselves & fastened with these

(3, 2).clue: Tamil is spoken in this country's state of Tamil Nadu, which was once known as Madras

(6, 2).clue: I started riding elephants, then went on to swing with the Monkees & sold 65 million records

(1, 3).clue: In a 1951 address to Congress, this general said that "In war there is no substitute for victory"

(2, 3).clue: Term for a jacket with a front closing that overlaps enough to allow for 2 rows of buttons

(3, 3).clue: Willem-Alexander, the eldest son of Queen Beatrix, is the heir to this country's throne

(6, 3).clue: In the 1959 Sears, Roebuck catalog I modeled underwear; later I went on to host "That's Incredible!"

(1, 4).clue: Miss. senator who in 1861 announced that his state had "declared her separation from the United States"

(3, 4).clue: Nanduti, a lace that looks like spider webs, is made in Itaugua, a town near Asuncion in this country

(6, 4).clue: I drove around "Vega$" in a little red T-Bird & drove around Boston in a '65 Mustang

(1, 5).clue: His last words were "How were the circus receipts today at Madison Square Garden?"

(3, 5).clue: In 1896 this capital on the Danube became the 1st city in eastern Europe to have a subway

(4, 5).clue: This old-time Washington Senators pitcher held the career strikeout record until Nolan Ryan broke it in 1983

(6, 5).clue: I've been hosting & producing the nationally syndicated dance show "Soul Train" for 2 decades

(1, 1).clue: The buildup of this insecticide in some birds & fish led to its restriction in 1972

(2, 1).clue: "The Lodger", a 1913 novel by Mrs. Belloc Lowndes, is a ripping yarn about his London crimes

(4, 1).clue: The Bozeman, Overland & Oregon ones all crossed Wyoming

(5, 1).clue: This Gershwin opera was not performed at the Met until 1985

(6, 1).clue: His 1904 Nobel Prize was for work on digestion, not conditioned reflexes in dogs

(1, 2).clue: Used to preserve biological specimens, it's the simplest of the organic compounds called aldehydes

(2, 2).clue: Harold Adrian Russell Philby, who spied for the Soviets, was better known by this nickname

(3, 2).clue: In 1966 his "Foundation" trilogy won a Hugo Award for the best all-time science fiction series

(4, 2).clue: The Buffalo Bill Historical Center is in this city

(5, 2).clue: "The Marriage of Figaro" was the first of 3 collaborations between Lorenzo da Ponte & this composer

(6, 2).clue: This American "jungle doctor" didn't have to hang down his head when he founded hospitals in Laos

(1, 3).clue: Once widely used as an anesthetic, CHCl3 is the chemical symbol for this

(2, 3).clue: He was a prior of a Dominican convent many years before he became Grand Inquisitor of Spain

(3, 3).clue: He died in 1975 shortly after publishing his last Nero Wolfe novel, "A Family Affair"

(4, 3).clue: "Geographical" term for Jim Bridger, Jedediah Smith & others who trapped in the state

(5, 3).clue: The Unattractive Tonio in "I Pagliacci" has this profession

(6, 3).clue: This man was the first person to become a qualified pediatrician & psychiatrist

(1, 4).clue: Astronomers knew very little about Pluto until this moon was discovered in 1978

(2, 4).clue: Dutch Schultz was 1 of the most famous victims of this organization of killers for hire

(3, 4).clue: Nevil Shute's novels "A Town Like Alice" & "On the Beach" are largely set in this country

(4, 4).clue: It's the name of a river, Cheyenne's county & the city that's home to the University of Wyoming

(5, 4).clue: She sang in a Baptist church in Philadelphia before she became the Met's first black soloist

(6, 4).clue: Frederick Leboyer's controversial approach to this includes dim light & a warm bath

(1, 5).clue: An important source for vit. A, this group of pigments gives pumpkins & apricots their color

(2, 5).clue: Prince Felix Yusupov & his conspirators threw this man in the Neva River in 1916

(3, 5).clue: This author of "Gorky Park" has also written under the pen names of Jake Logan & Martin Quinn

(4, 5).clue: After this governor died in 1924, his wife was elected to complete his term of office

(5, 5).clue: Enrico Caruso made his U.S. debut on November 23, 1903 as the Duke of Mantua in this opera

(6, 5).clue: Doctor Yelena Bonner is the widow of this Soviet dissident

(0, 0).clue: Ronald Reagan, Errol Flynn, Richard Mulligan & Gary Cole have all played this historical role
